dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, but large cave in the depths of the Motoyama Mountains of Iwo Jima. The hand carved walls show striations of pick axes from many years past. A PHOTOGRAPHER makes notes on his clipboard and takes flash pictures of labeled artifacts laid out on the floor -- a dust covered BOOT, a rusted and dented CANTEEN. A group of JAPANESE EXCAVATORS wearing hard hats with the words “Association of Iwo Jima” emblazoned on them, carefully dig the floor with shovels. The dirt is thrown into wooden boxes with rhythmic THUMPS, and carried out to be sifted. Drenched with sweat and their faces red with exertion, the excavators wither under the humid heat.

dialogues.speaker: EXCAVATOR
dialogues.text: How did those soldiers dig out these tunnels in the first place? Exhausted, Excavator #1 has to pause.

dialogues.speaker: EXCAVATOR
dialogues.text: Let’s get a rotation in here. He starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: EXCAVATOR
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. His shovel hits something which looks like a LEATHER SATCHEL. The two Excavators take a closer look and carefully dig around the artifact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they pierce the black sandy dirt of the beach. They dig in and lift. The voice of PVF. KATSUHIRO SAIGO, in his thirties, reads a letter.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To Hanakg. We soldiers dig. We dig .all day. We dig holes where we are to stand when battle comes. Holes just big enough to stand in. Not wide enough to move forward or to move back. Holes where we are expected to fight and stay in until we die, for die we most likely will.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL --
dialogues.text: An entire beach lined with trenches and SOLDIERS digging. The sun beats down on their sweat-drenched backs. SUPERIMPOSE: IWO JIMA ISLAND, JUNE 1944. Other soldiers maneuver artillery pieces into position or work on constructing bunkers and pillboxes -- buried huts for housing machine guns and antitank weapons.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hanako, now I know what it feels like to dig my own grave. Saigo wipes his face dirtied with the black sand. He has an unrefined look, but with kind eyes and an energetic demeanor. He’s seen enough in life to either make him wise or a wise-ass. A FLAG of the Japanese Navy & Army, bearing the sun motif with banded rays, flutters on the beach encampment. Overhead, a PLANE approaches the island. INT. PLANE HEADED TOWARDS IWO — DAY LT. GENERAL TADAMICHI KURIBAYASHI, fifty-three, staunch and tall, with an air of regality, sits on a bench of the supply plane.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Today, I head for my post where my men are stationed. To avoid detection by the enemy, I take a supply plane and the hour of my arrival remains unannounced. My heart is as strong as that of General Kusonoki who gave his life for Japan 650 years ago at the Minato River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ke ie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: te i  3

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi looks out a window as the plane descends.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I hope you and the children are well. I’m sorry I wasn’t able to attend to the kitchen floor before I left. Make sure to have Taro take care of it as those drafts may give you a cold. As the plane approaches Iwo Jima, the island materializes below like a large, brown pork chop. The distinct dome- shaped volcano, Mt. Suribachi, rises up out of the South end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black-sanded beach is busy with the activity of soldiers. The men dig at different intervals from one another. PVT. KASHIWARA digs in the hole next to Saigo’s.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Damn this island! The Americans can have it. He continues digging as he mutters.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Nothing grows here, it smells, it’s hot, there are too many damn bugs and there’s no water.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: This island is part of Japan’s sacred homeland. :

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing sacred about this island. CAPTAIN TANIDA, late twenties, and sharply dressed, walks along the trenches inspecting. Kashiwara sees him and tries to warn Saigo.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: Hey Saigo! Hey! Saigo ignores Kashiwara as he continues grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: We should just give this island to the Ameritans, and then we can go home.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: What did you say, soldier? Saigo finally sees the Captain and puts his shovel down. Salutes.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Sir, I said if we beat the Americans, then we can go home. Captain Tanida looks at Kashiwara.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: You there. Is that what he said? Kashiwara seems helpless. There is a moment of hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADMIRAL OHSUGI, forties, waits patiently on the beach along with his OFFICER STAFF MEMBERS. Finally, the war-torn plane drones in for a landing. It lands safely on the landing strip. Kuribayashi steps off onto the tarmac. LT. FUJITA, twenties, Kuribayashi’s personal aide, follows behind him. . They makes their way to Ohsugi and exchange salutes.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Welcome, General Kuribayashi. I’m Admiral Ohsugi. They bow politely.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: How long have you been waiting here for me? Ohsugi checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Three hours, ~sér.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear. They wouldn’t allow me to wire my arrival after what happened to Admiral Yamamoto.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: I understand, sir. Kuribayashi turns to Lt. Fujita.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: This is my aide, Lieutenant Fujita. Admiral Ohsugi and Lt. Fujita bow to each other. Ohsugi touches his stomach and grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Admiral? You don’t look very well.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s nothing, sir. The water here does not agree with me.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that. Ohsugi motions the way.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: This way to your quarters.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Admiral, I want to make a round of the island first.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Shall I fetch a jeep?

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: No, let’s walk. Walking’s good for the health. It might be just what you need, Ohsugi- He chuckles, but Ohsugi does not look pleased. They walk together, while the members of the staff walk a respectful 3 paces behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: esta re

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi stops in front of a view of the cone-shaped volcano, MT. SURTBACHT on the South end of the island.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: I could see it from the plane. Mt. Suribachi. That’s the first place the Americans will want to take, Ohsugi.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE BEACH
dialogues.text: Captain Tanida quickly finds a stick and whips Saigo and Kashiwara with it. The two grimace with the pain. Tanida doesn’t notice when Kuribayashi and his entourage pass by behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: You no good peasants! Scums! Kuribayashi approaches Captain Tanida, who immediately stands at attention and stops beating Saigo and Kashiwara.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Captain, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: These soldiers were conspiring with unpatriotic words, sir. Kuribayashi looks over at the haggard looking soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: I see. And Captain, do you have such an excess of soldiers that you can put two of them out of commission? Captain Tanida is hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Then stop beating them. Deny their lunch rations instead. Ohsugi and Tanida look at each other, miffed.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: A good captain uses his brain, not just his whip. :

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. a

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: And what is all this?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: This? Trenches, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHIT
dialogues.text: Why are the men digging trenches here? Tanida looks to Ohsugi once again for support.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: This is where the Americans are expected to land, sir. Kuribayashi looks at the men digging.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Have them stop immediately.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: But, sir...

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: If you had studied Tarawa, you would know that concentrating our defenses at the beach would be futile. Captain Tanida is hesitant. Kuribayashi gives him a firm look. Captain Tanida turns towards the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Stop digging! The men stop and look up, surprised. Kuribayashi turns to Captain Tanida.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: And Captain, make sure these men get proper breaks. They look like they’re from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers sit on the sand, eating out of their mess kits. All except Saigo and Kashiwara who watch them hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: b

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kashiwara rubs his stomach. - © KASHTWARA Just a8 well. My stomach’s been bothering me anyway. A soldier on water duty comes by with a pitcher, and they are allowed a tiny cupful, which they take gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: A toast to General Kuribayashi. A fine commander. Kashiwara drinks as well.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Mmmmm. Better than sake. PVT. NOZAKI, another soldier in his thirties, comes to join them.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: I heard he lived in America. Maybe that’s why he doesn’t want us digging trenches. Maybe he likes the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: No, stupid. He studied the Americans, so now he knows how to beat them.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: I heard from someone in the 204th that another general was supposed to command the island, but he didn’t want the job, so Premier Tojo gave it to Kuribayashi instead.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: You hear a lot of things, Nozaki, but your ears are full of wax! Nozaki brushes him off.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Anyway, you can’t trust anyone from the 204th. They’re part of the Navy. I think this Kuribayashi must be a superb general. Look, we're not digging those damn trenches in the sand anymore, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kashiwara’s stomach makes a large GROWLING noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi inspects a map of Iwo Jima with defense plans marked. Admiral Ohsugi and a stern looking Naval officer, LIEUTENANT ITO, are in the room with him.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHIT
dialogues.text: How many planes do we have?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: 41 Zekes and 13 bombers.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: We sent 66 planes to reinforce the fleet at Saipan. Kuribayashi looks grave.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: We will have to rely on support from the Combined Fleet. He turns his attention to defense maps.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: These are your defense plans?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHIT
dialogues.text: And what about the army troops? Where will they be stationed? Ohsugi hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I don’t know exactly. They are under the command of Col... Adachi. Kuribayashi looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: " KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: You haven't coordinated your plans?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: Col. Adachi prefers that we do not interfere*with each other’s chain of command.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: This is no time for childish games, Admiral. This is war. Ohsugi feels the sting. Kuribayashi sighs and goes back to looking at the map.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: This will not work. You are concentrating all your efforts on the beaches. Move the artillery to higher ground.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ITO
dialogues.text: But sir, we just had them moved down to the beaches.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Well, move them back up. We’1l need fortifications at Suribachi. Coordinate with Col. Adachi and have them start immediately.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ITO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Ohsugi walks briskly with Lt. Ito, annoyed. ADMIRAL OHSUGI . This one’s trouble. Lt. Ito nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ITO
dialogues.text: Army commanders usually are, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Tanida barks commands like a fierce little pit bull. Saigo, Kashiwara and Nozaki stand to attention. 10. 10

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Our new ordersyhave come in for the day! Prepare for relocation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers dig at the base of the volcano. The men are stripped to the waist in the heat. Now the dirt they dig is more like lava, still steaming with heat.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: It stinks. Saigo lifts up a dirt-full and some of it falls on his back.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Damn Kuribayashi!

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: Shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Come on! Dig! Put your backs into it. Saigo mutters to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi inspects A MAP on the wall highlighting areas once occupied at the height of the Japanese Empire in 1943, The “Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.” The area stretches over a vast circle over the Pacific. Covered with pins of Japanese flags, the map shows locations of strategic forces. White flags represent areas won back by the Allied forces. The white flags encroach on the Japanese flags.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Under curfew, the streets of Tokyo are mostly dark and unlit. CAPTAIN IWASAKI, a stern looking Kempeitai officer patrols the street.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: te

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Next to him is YOICHI. SHIMIZU, 17. Everything about Shimizu is orderly and pristine, from his shiny boots, to his perfectly .alignéd cap. Both wear a WHITE BAND on their left arm with kanji characters, “Ken” (law) and “Hei” (soldier) inscribed on them.

dialogues.speaker: -SHIMIZU, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To mother. I am proud to say I graduated training with flying colors and I will be training under the guidance of Captain Iwasaki. It fills my heart with joy to serve my Emperor and the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. You can rest assured there won't be any spies or Communists under my watch. Thank you for the rice crackers, but please don’t send anymore. We must all conserve our food rations for the war effort. Luxury is the enemy. Saving is the road to victory. A BICYCLIST rides through the main street, ringing his bell. Captain Iwasaki yells at the Bicyclist as he passes them by.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: You there! The Bicyclist halts.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: You should not be riding right in the middle of the street like that. What if there were an air raid or a military convoy coming through here? The Bicyclist looks frightened. He bows in compliance.

dialogues.speaker: BICYCLIST
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: Get off to one side there. The Bicyclist complies. Officer Iwasaki turns to Shimizu.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: Remember, Shimizu, as Kempeitai, you have all the authority, so don’t be intimidated by a person's age. You have complete control.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They arrive at, an office building with a signage Chuo Koron Magazine and bust the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimizu roughly rummages through PAPERS. A JOURNALIST, late forties, watches nervously, while Captain Iwasaki stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: You are suspected of violating the Peace Preservation Law. Shimizu continues to go through papers and magazines, throwing useless ones on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Tell me which article it was. I’m sure I have complied to all the rules --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet! The Journalist stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Look, I have a family to support. Just let me know what it was and I'll retract the article. He takes out his wallet and lays out his cash on the table. Shimizu looks at the cash, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Do you think we can be bribed? How dare you insult us!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN IWASAKI
dialogues.text: Shimizu, I’1l find the articles. Take care®of him. Shimizu nods in compliance and strong-arms the Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Just a minute.. Shimizu leads him out the door as he protests. Captain Iwasaki deftly takes the money off the table and pockets it. Then he confiscates copies of the magazine Chuo Koron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIVATE FIRST CLASS YAMAZAKI mans the POSTAL TENT, relaxing with a copy of a magazine. Saigo walks to him and hands over a letter.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKI
dialogues.text: Another letter? You know that the mail only goes out when there’s a boat available, don’t you? Saigo laughs, ‘embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: I have a lot of family.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKT
dialogues.text: Then how come all your letters are addressed to your wife? Saigo gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Nosey.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKI
dialogues.text: Here let me do you a favor. Otherwise, your letters will never make it through. He opens Saigo’s letter.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you doing? 4 15

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKI
dialogues.text: I used to workeat the Office of Censorship in Tokyo, you know, before I got transferred.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Transferred? You mean demoted? Yamazaki tries to ignore the last comment. He reads the letter.

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKI
dialogues.text: (reading) “To Hanako. We soldiers dig...” No, no, no. This will never pass. He starts crossing off lines of Saigo’s letter.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hey! Private Yamazaki continues blacking out lines. Most of Saigo’s letter is crossed out as he reads/mumbles the rest of the letter. He suddenly LAUGHS out loud.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Give me that back! Yamazaki finishes crossing off the letter so that the only lines that remain are "To Hanako,” and "Hope you are doing well.”

dialogues.speaker: PRIVATE YAMAZAKI
dialogues.text: There. You’ll thank me for this later, Saigo. He seals the letter back up. Saigo grumbles as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo and the men have rifle practice. Each soldier gets their turn at hitting a bulls-eye. Kuribayashi stands watching from a distance. One of the soldier’s gun jams and he fiddles with it. Another is slow to aim.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Faster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ses tittinte! 16 17 16.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi continues to watch, disappointment registering on his face. © When it’s Saigo’s turn, he aims his rifle. At the last minute, he jerks his gun. His shot is way off the mark. Captain Tanida storms up to him and shouts in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Saigo, are you blind? Can’t you see the target? Even my 6 year old could shoot better than you do. Saigo bows his head in apology.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Do it again. Saigo fumbles. He aims his rifle and once again, his shot is way off the mark. Captain Tanida hits the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: You‘re an embarrassment! -You’re a poor excuse for a soldier. Tonight, you will clean the boots of your entire troop. Go to the rear! Kuribayashi turns to Lt. Fujita.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Better they should learn to clean their guns properly rather than their boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Kuribayashi, with a company of army soldiers, marches through the local village. Ever his shadow, Lt. Fujita marches alongside him. It’s a small town with a dusty main street, a bar, general store and single-story houses bedecked with banners. Children, women and grandparents run out to greet the men with Rising Sun flags and cheer them on. Kuribayashi notices a collection of idle TANKS in the village with a few ARMY MECHANICS working on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i. f

dialogues.speaker: NM KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: What are thosestanks doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: Those are out of commission, sir. They are waiting for parts.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Waiting for parts? How long have they been like this.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: I have been told about a month, sir. Kuribayashi looks again at the tanks. A LITTLE BOY of about four plays in the foreground with toy tanks.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The streets are jammed with cars, HONKING, and stalled in traffic. Kuribayashi sits on a park bench with HARVARD UNIVERSITY in the b.g., a stack of textbooks beside him. Kuribayashi sketches a picture of a car in a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To Taro, from Father. This is a picture of a car. America is filled with cars. I have to be very careful when crossing the streets. Cars come from every direction. Even my maid has a car. Japan has a lot of catching up to do with America. Kuribayashi looks up again at the traffic jam.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Taro, are you minding your mother? I wish you were here with me. Kuribayashi pulls out a picture of his young son, TARO. aa END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi is still focused on the young boy playing in front of the idle tanks. He turns to Fujita.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: These civilians need to be evacuated as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo is busy cleaning stacks of shoes. Kashiwara approaches him with his own boots.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: Saigo, I know that you must be a better shot than that after a year and a half. Saigo doesn’t look up from his cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: I have no aim, that’s all. Kashiwara hesitates for a moment, shakes his head and leaves his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi with walking stick in hand, makes his way briskly across the beach. He sees the mountains in the Northern hills and heads. over towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi stares at the mountains, starts to climb up one of them. He carefully ascends and peers into one of the natural caves. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The village is now an empty ghost town. The flags have all been taken down, turning the city from colorful to monochromatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Only bits of litter remain, scattering in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo and other members of his troop tear down a school house, collecting the wood into piles. Captain Tanida inspects another nearby structure.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: We can use the wood from this one as well. All the men stop when they hear the sound of a GALLOPING HORSE. They turn to see BARON TAKEICHI NISHI, tall, handsome and gallant, riding with gusto towards them.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hanako, we have a celebrity in our midst. Do you remember Baron Nishi, the Olympic gold medalist in horse jumping? He has just arrived from Tokyo and is stationed here as Commander of the 26th Tank Regiment. The men watch as he rides full speed, and hurdles over a fence. A study in grace and agility. The men CLAP. Baron Nishi smiles and salutes them as he rides on.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Get back to work, men. Baron Nishi nearly mows Captain Tanida over as he gallops away.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel Nishi is very handsome, so I’m sure the rumors of his womanizing skills must be true, but there are no women left on the island to woo. He is friendly with the troops and sometimes talks casually among them. Strange for a Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi walks along the sand with his walking stick. He stops when he sees Baron Nishi approaching, sand flying from his horse's heels.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Baron Nishi dismounts his horse, his spurred boots 20. 24 CLINKING as they hit the ground. He salutes Kuribayashi. General Kuribayashi walks up to Baron Nishi and they shake hands like Westerners.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHL
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel Nishi. I used to be a cavalryman myself, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHT
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. I’ve been looking forward to serving under you. One who understands horses the way I do.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Those were the days, when soldiers could ride in on horses. Not these mechanized contraptions. Kuribayashi admires the horse.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHT
dialogues.text: I could send for another horse and we could ride together, General.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: I’m afraid my riding days are over, Nishi. But tell me about this famous horse of yours that you won the Olympics with.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: My stallion, Uranus? + He pulls out a picture of Uranus, a stallion of Anglo- Norman stock, and shows it to Kuribayashi.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: That’s a fine horse.

dialogues.speaker: BARON . NISHI
dialogues.text: The Italians thought I was doing them a favor, getting rid of him to me. No one could tame the beast, but I told them ‘If that’s a really headstrong horse, it’s just the one for me, a headstrong man.’ They share a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: I’m dying for: some news from the mainland on the war effort. We mostly just hear what they filter on the radio broadcasts.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: I understand. It’s hard to know what’s really going on these days.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Dine with me tonight. And if you have brought any sake back with you, that would be a double welcome.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: I think that can be arranged, sir. INT. OFFICER’S QUARTERS - NIGHT 25 Kuribayashi and Baron Nishi sit at a table with cups of sake before them. The COOK enters and serves them plates of fish and rice. He then continues to place empty plates on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Is that still really necessary?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Regulations, sir. Baron Nishi looks at Kuribayashi questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI,
dialogues.text: I have told our cook that all officers will have the same rations and food as our men. The Cook looks flustered.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: It is not right. Officers should not eat the same food.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Apparently, military regulations dictates that officers must be served at least three dishes.

dialogues.speaker: . COOK
dialogues.text: That's right. At least three dishes. This is a travesty, sir. I am very ashamed. The Cook finishes placing the empty dishes.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: So as a compromise, I told him he could bring out empty dishes. The Cook bows and exits.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBYASHI
dialogues.text: He’s a stubborn son of a bitch. I had to give in to him. kuribayashi and Nishi LAUGH. Kuribayashi jovially pours another cup of sake in Baron Nishi’s cup.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: We will defeat the enemy this time, Nishi. It will be different from past island battles.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: I'm sure it will be, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: After all, Iwo Tou is part of Japanese soil. Kuribayashi sips his sake.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: When the enemy arrive, we will contain them, and then our Combined Fleet will take them out. Blast them back to America. Baron Nishi turns grave and is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: General, there is no longer any Combined Fleet.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHT
dialogues.text: I guess you haven’t heard about what happened with Operation A-Go ten days ago. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BARON NISHI (cont'd) Most of Admiral Ozawa’s carrier planes and float planes were destroyed off the Marianas. We still have some scattered naval forces, but there will be no striking power from the air, or sea for that matter. Kuribayashi looks dark, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: You must be drunk. This island is under the jurisdiction of the city of Tokyo. We'll get our support.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: If you want my honest opinion, the best thing to do would be to sink this island to the bottom of the sea. Baron Nishi takes a large gulp of the sake. Kuribayashi is speechless, his jovial mood wiped out.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHIT
dialogues.text: And yet, you still came.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHT
dialogues.text: Well, I figured your men were going to need all the tanks I could bring. This brings a light smile back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi looks over the strategic plans. He slowly removes all air attack force plans from the table model. He stands over the table in grave contemplation, then angrily pulls strategic PLAN PAPERS off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi strides along the beach with Fujita behind him.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: This beach is wide. Yes, the enemy must land here. They have no alternative. Kuribayashi rushes the beach. Fujita watches him, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Fujita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Run along the beach there.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: Six?

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Like you’re one of the Americans. Go on. Which direction would you take? Fujita contemplates for a minute, then rushes up towards the airfield. Kuribayashi quickly takes up a position and aims his walking stick at Fujita, pretending to shoot, moves around, looks for another vantage point. He looks at the surroundings, measuring where the best positions would be.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Okay, come from the other side. Fujita complies. Kuribayashi takes up another position and mock shoots him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kashiwara and Saigo stare in awe at the beach activity.

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: I think your general is a bit nuts. Captain Tanida strides up the slopes barking commands.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Break time is over! Back to work! The men get up immediately. Kashiwara suddenly bowls over from a cramp. Saigo looks at him concerned.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: You don’t look so good. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t fs ie fe fr t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By

dialogues.speaker: KASHIWARA
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Jugt the damn water, I’m sure. But I really need to go. He quickly makes his way to a discrete location behind the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi walks along the hillside with a gaggle of Officers struggling to keep up with him. Admiral Ohsugi, aging 57-year-old COLONEL ADACHI and MAJ. GENERAL SATO are among them. Finally, Kuribayashi comes to a stop and turns to the officers. ‘ KURIBAYASHI Our strategy will be to take a defensive position and use the terrain to our advantage. We will build caves and tunnels in the mountains, place our artillery along this ridge and Suribachi.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: What about the beaches?

dialogues.speaker: , KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: The men will have a clear view of the beaches from Suribachi and Motoyama. There is no need to fortify the beaches.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: General Kuribayashi, you must understand that the trenches are the first line of defense. We must resume work on the beaches.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: General, do you know how many cars America produces in a year? Five million. Five million cars, General. The American forces and their technological advancements should not be underestimated. The Americans will cross the beaches eventually and the soldiers’ lives will be needlessly wasted there.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: It's inevitable that men will die. But I’ve never heard of an island operation without a line of defense at the beaches.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: And how long did our guns last along the beaches at Saipan and Guam? Will you please show me just how effective the beach pillboxes at Tarawa were? The officers are silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: So we build tunnels and caves in the mountains?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: It will be a futile waste of time. a The men cannot dig through a fos mountain. Besides, what kind of war is fought in caves?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: The strategy should be to force the ships in for a heavy air attack.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: I agree. That makes the most sense. We will have support from our Combined Fleet. Kuribayashi is quiet for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: We can no longer count on our Combined Fleet.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: The Combined Fleet has been broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers look at each other with gravity.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: What’s more, “Isreceived an order on the wire this morning that all our remaining planes are to be sent back to Tokyo to defend the mainland.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: We won't be able to last five days without air support.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: We will hold the island as long as possible, no matter the outcome. Once the Americans take Iwo Tou, they will have a clear route for their bombing runs. But if we can draw out the battle, hold this island for at least 20 days, the Americans will think twice about attacking Japan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN comes down in torrents, a tropical storm in the midst of ‘the heat. Tarps that have been put up to collect the water fill up with the rain. Soldiers transfer the water from the tarp into buckets and haul them to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another rainy day on the island.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Shimizu steps off an air carrier along with other soldiers. He looks around him, carrying his pack.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: fo mother, today I am to join my new unit. I know you have been wondering about my transfer. This is something I cannot discuss now, but I will explain to you some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 INT. TROOP’S CAVE..—_DAY (DEC. 1944) The soldiers lie on their bedrolls, reading books, 32 writing letters or mending their uniforms. Even though it’s winter, the men are stripped to their undershirts and try to fan themselves in the heat. Saigo reads a BOOK with pictures of Egypt on the cover. Saigo shows Nozaki a page from the book.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Look at this picture.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: That’s some fancy castle.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: You know who that castle was made for? Somebody who was already dead.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: They must have had a lot of money back then to make a castle. like that for a dead person. Why are you reading a book about Egypt anyway? We’re never going to war over there.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: (ignoring) We'll be lucky if we even get a hole in the ground when we’re dead.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKT
dialogues.text: Don’t talk about that. It’s bad luck. Shimizu enters the cave. Despite the rain, his uniform still looks crisp and clean.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Here comes the new recruit.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Is this the 312th?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: That’s right. Saigo continues reading his book.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Se NOZAKI I’m Nozaki. ~Teis is Saigo.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Shimizu, Yoichi.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: You can put your bedroll there, Shimizu. He points to an empty space. Shimizu is about to put his bedroll down, but Saigo tries to prevent him.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: There’s another empty space at the back end of the cave.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: {to Shimizu) Don’t mind him. His friend Kashiwara just died. That used to be his spot. Shimizu methodically puts his bedroll out, where Kashiwara’s spot used to be.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: But. we are all going to die. That’s our plan, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: If it serves the country, it is a death of honor.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Kashiwara died of honorable | dysentery.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Where are you from, Shimizu?

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: From Kanagawa-ken.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Kanagawa-ken. Ozawa is from there, aren’t you? . OZAWA, a young soldier in his twenties, nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: OZAWA
dialogues.text: That’s right. Where did you train? Maybe we were at the same camp.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: i i t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimizu is hesitant. “= suimrzu No, I trained in Tokyo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beak

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: I trained in Tokyo, too. What camp was it? Shimizu is hesitant again. é SHIMIZU The Koho Kimmu Yoin Yoseijo. Everyone becomes silent. Shimizu turns to continue unpacking his bedroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nozaki quickly leaves his vicinity and sidles up to Saigo.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Why do you think they put a Kempeitai in our unit?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: He’s not wearing the white arm band. He’s not Kempeitai.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: He went to the Kempeitai military academy.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Maybe he flunked out. Nozaki notices a holstered PISTOL on Shimizu's belt.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: i He acts like a Kempeitai. And : look at his holster. That’s not standard issue. And are riflemen even supposed to have pistols? He’s been put here to spy on us.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Why would he spy on us?

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s those letters you’ve been writing. JI think you should be careful what you say, Saigo. \

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Saigo looks worried. They watch Shimizu. He sits down and pulls out a small migror, checks his closely cropped hair. He jumps up suddenly with a YELL. A CENTIPEDE crawls on him. Nozaki and Saigo try to suppress their smirks. Shimizu looks embarrassed. He stomps on the insect angrily. ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers line up for their lunchtime rations. They each get a bowl of soup with weeds floating in them.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Weed soup again? They look over towards Shimizu, who stands behind them in line.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKT
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi’s conserving our food supplies for the battle. Saigo and Nozaki sit down. Shimizu sits slightly apart from the rest of the men. He looks at his soup, trying to suppress his shock. He digs in and eats without comment. Saigo looks at Shimizu and then back into his soup.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: We'll be dead before the Americans even get here. And you would think with all my war effort contributions, we should be eating kasutera cakes or sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: I ran a bakery shop in Tokyo with my wife. We sold kasutera and ampan cakes, back when we could still get sugar. Saigo motions towards Shimizu.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: His kempeitai brethren used to come in 4nd take what they wanted. Said it was for the war effort.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: We ran in to those types at our clothing store as well.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: When we started making sandwiches, they took those too. And when we ran out of meat and just had bread, they still came. Finally, they took our baking equipment for the metal and we were out of business. {a beat) I should have been a fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: It must be hard on your wife without the shop and without a husband.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: HANAKO sweeps the floor of the empty bakery shop, pausing to rub her swollen belly. \ There is a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo sits on a mat on the floor reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Tell them to go away. We have nothing to sell.

dialogues.speaker: BAKERY SHOP
dialogues.text: Hanako opens the door. Her face turns pale. SATGO (v.0.) Who is it? A CITY CLERK and WOMEN FROM THE PATRIOTIC WOMEN’S ASSOCIATION, wearing governmental sashes stand at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The City Clerk holds out a red letter. He bows with the letter outstretched in-his hand. Hanako stares at it and does not take it. — :

dialogues.speaker: LEAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Your husband’s going to war. Saigo comes to the door. He also turns pale when he sees the red letter, but tries to compose himself. He takes it and bows to them.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. I’m happy to serve the nation. The LEAD WOMAN, in her forties, steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Prayers for your eternal success at arms.

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: Please. We have only each other. Lead Woman gives Hanako a look of anger.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hanako, go to the back, dear.

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: He’s already been to war once.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: We have all sent our husbands to war, Mrs. Saigo. And our sons. We all have to do our part. She looks at Hanako’s belly.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD WOMAN
dialogues.text: At least you'll have a little one to carry on your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo and Hanako sit across from each other at the dinner table. There is a meager ration of rice gruel and dried fish. Hanako is unable to eat and weeps silently. Saigo puts his chopsticks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: srvereesane 34. eo

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hanako, I can’t taste the food with you tike that.

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: What am I going to do after you die?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Am I already in the coffin?

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: The men never come back. Don’t you see all the black streamers flying in our village? They never come back. They’re not supposed to come back. She weeps some more. Saigo comes over to her side.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: And now, with the baby... She ledns into him.

dialogues.speaker: HANAKO
dialogues.text: I’m scared. Saigo bends over and puts his ear to her stomach, then talks to it.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hey, little baby. This is your father speaking. Let me tell you a secret. You're not to repeat this to anyone, okay? (whispering) I plan to come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanako brightens when she hears this. END OF FLASHBACK. 36 EXT. MOTOYAMA CAVES -— DAY (1944) 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of PICK AXES CLANGING against STONE WALLS Fes emanates from a complex network of multilevel caves and : tunnels in the Motoyama mountainside.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Saigo, Nozaki and Shimizu work in a separate area where sulfurous HOT STEAM riseg from the rocks. They wear GAS MASKS to protect themselves. The mountain is like a busy anthill where men dig, remove, cart and carry. Baron Nishi, still wearing his spurred boots, directs his men on camouflaging tanks in gunner positions. Kuribayashi looks at his plans, comparing the work to his map. He remains unnoticed by Admiral Ohsugi and Lt. Ito as he walks behind them.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. Why waste time digging these impossible caves when they are all going to die anyway? Lr. ITO At least he has conceded to the pillboxes on the beaches. Kuribayashi continues to walk on. INT. OFFICER’S QUARTERS - NIGHT 37 General Kuribayashi sits at his desk, writing a memo. Admiral Ohsugi enters.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Yes, Admiral. Kuribayashi continues writing and Admiral Ohsugi has to wait patiently. Finally, Kuribayashi looks up.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Admiral Ohsugi, you have been looking quite pale these days.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: It’s the water. It has never agreed with me.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: I think you need to go back to Tokyo to recoup.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi hands him the memo. Admiral Ohsugi look$ at it and is momentarily speechless.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: I have just commissioned Admiral Ichimaru to take your place.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: General, the island won’t last more than five days without fleet support. I’m not alone in thinking the cave work is... i futile. Kuribayashi stands up from the table, angered.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: The cave digging may be futile. Maybe the stand on Iwo Tou will be futile. Maybe the whole war is futile. But will you give up then? What will we tell the people of Japan? Admiral Ohsugi, we will stay and hold this island until we die, until every last breath of us is expired. If my children can live to see one more day of a free Japan, that would be worth the one more day that we suffer instead of surrender. So don't tell me that the cave work is futile. He sits back down. Admiral Ohsugi looks defeated.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, General. I was mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: You are dismissed. Admiral Ohsugi turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh from a ride,. Baron Nishi fondly brushes his horse' coat.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: Hey, Jupiter. That's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Ohsugi walks in the direction of the airstrip. Behind him, his AIDE follows, carrying his bags. General Sato sees him on the way. They stop and salute each other.

dialogues.speaker: . GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: It’s true then. I didn’t believe it when I heard. Admiral Ohsugi tries not to show his humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: I’m glad to be gone from this island.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: We may have had our differences, but I’m truly sorry to see you go. Admiral Ohsugi starts on his way again, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL OHSUGI
dialogues.text: General Sato, it’s up to you now. I hate to say it, but Kuribayashi belongs back behind a desk at the Imperial Palace, not commanding a war. Baron Nishi emerges from the horse pen and overhears the two talking. General Sato nods.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: I understand. There are many of us whose sentiments are with you. Ohsugi continues on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, OUTDOOR INSTRUCTIONAL HUT
dialogues.text: Saigo, Shimizu and Nozaki sit in a hut for an instructional lecture, with Captain Tanida speaking.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: The Americans are likely to land here. He points to the South beach on a map of Iwo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [i f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: re

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN TANIDA bes Cross fire positions will be here, : here and Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : He points to Motoyama and Suribachi.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Now, to be truthful, we will likely be outnumbered by the : Americans in troop size and air g and naval support. But we have a great advantage. Can anyone tell me what that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers look at each other at a loss, still trying to digest the fact that they will be outnumbered in all aspects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Shimizu stands up.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: The Americans are weak-willed and inferior to Japanese soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Very good, Shimizu. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: They are not as disciplined and let their feelings interfere with their fighting.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: That is correct. Saigo and Nozaki give each other looks, distrustful of Shimizu. zg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Tanida displays a picture of a uniformed American

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i medic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the uniform of an American medic. He should be your target, for Americans will risk the lives of many soldiers to save this one. 41 INT. COMMAND HUT - DAY 4l Kuribayashi stands, looking at the map of the Empire. Soe The number of white flags has proliferated, while the ane Japanese flags have diminished. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l 42 39. CONTINUED : Al Kuribayashi turns towards Baron Nishi. = «

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: What is it. that you wanted to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: I just thought I'd warn you, sir, to keep an eye on your commanders.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Thank you for your concern, Nishi, but I have it under control. Admiral Ohsugi is gone and I trust General Sato and Colonel Adachi will keep things in order. Baron Nishi looks unconvinced. ADMIRAL ICHIMARU, the new naval officer, walks into the command hut. His right leg has been injured from a previous war wound, and he limps as he walks in.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ICHIMARU
dialogues.text: Admiral Ichimaru reporting for duty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Ah, Admiral Ichimaru.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He bows to them and starts to leave, when the WAIL of an AIR RAID SIREN interrupts their greetings. The SIRENS are immediately followed by the DRONE of approaching B- 24s. : Kuribayashi grabs his paperwork. The men quickly make their way out of the tent. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo and the rest of the troop get up and run quickly from the huts seeking shelter. The squadron of planes descends upon them. STRAFING FIRE riddles the earth. Saigo. and. Nozaki jump behind a large rock formation. Shimizu finds shelter in a nearby trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As they watch, the SAND EXPLODES before them in black plumes. The men cover their heads from the falling debris. = - A BOMB disintegrates the instructional tent.that the men have just escaped. BOMBS continue to fall like explosive rain around the island. . The command hut is ablaze in a orange plume of fire. Finally, the bombing stops. Baron Nishi emerges from one of the trenches.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: Jupiter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron Nishi rushes out to the pen. The horse lies dead on the ground. Baron Nishi goes over to it. Falls on his knees, devastated. Pets its neck.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPGROUNDS 44
dialogues.text: The men start cleaning up the debris. Saigo picks up planks of wood when he sees Private Yamazaki in the distance, sitting upright. He approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey, Yamazaki. What are you doing just sitting there? Help us out here. Yamazaki does not respond. Saigo gets closer to him and reels back in horror. Yamazaki’s skull has been blasted out of his head, leaving his distorted face. INT. TROOP’S CAVE - NIGHT (FEBRUARY, 1945) 45 More AERIAL BOMB BLASTS can be heard outside the caves. Saigo, Shimizu, Nozaki, Ozawa and other troop members bide their.time in their sleeping quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimizu writes a letter.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To mother. We are being bombarded daily by B-24s. They fly at an altitude too high to be reached by our anti-aircraft guns. Officer Tanida estimates there have been over 20,000 shells on this tiny island. When the Americans finally arrive, we’ll give them our own Hell. The men look haggard, with rings under their eyes from lack of sleep. Nozaki approaches Saigo, motions towards Shimizu.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: I think he’s writing about us. In his reports.

dialogues.speaker: . SAIGO
dialogues.text: He’s just writing a letter. It’s been two months, Nozaki. He would have reported us by now.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: How can you be sure? They watch Shimizu. The GROUND RUMBLES with another bomb blast. OZAWA . Will they ever stop? Day and night. Day and night. It’s driving me nuts! A TIRED SOLDIER in his thirties, tries to sleep in his bedroll, covering his ears. Another EXPLOSION causes debris to rain down from the cave walls. The Tired Soldier finally gets up angrily.

dialogues.speaker: TIRED SOLDIER
dialogues.text: If the damn Americans are going to invade, why don’t they hurry up and land already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: psccotoket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOMBING NOISES are more distant in the deeper and larger cave of the Officer’s Quarters. Kuribayashi sits at his desk. He doodles a drawing on a letter he has written.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tako-chan. Your last letter was written very well. You used some very big words. You’ve grown very wise and I am very happy. You made just five errors in your kanji. This is a picture of your father walking around the island. Kuribayashi looks at a portrait of his family—-his wife, sone and two daughters. Lt. Fujita enters the cave holding a wire.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: General, the fleet of American ships have left Saipan. Kuribayashi stands to receive the note.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: So they are on their way. Have all beach positions manned and ready for action.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi turns on a microphone. Outside BOMBS continue to be dropped.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Men, the time has come at last to show your true colors. To fight as honorable men of the Imperial Japanese Army. INTERCUT - PLANNING ROOM/TROOP’S CAVE 48 Saigo, Shimizu and Nozaki stand at attention, as they listen to Kuribayashi’s voice over the LOUDSPEAKER.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHT
dialogues.text: Iwo Tou is of ytmost importance to our Nippon.- If the army takes this island, they will land their planes here, refuel and fly their bombs to the homeland. They will attack our villages and destroy them with fire bombs. For the sake of our homeland, we must delay them as long as possible. We cannot expect to return home. Saigo and Nozaki look at each other, the last sentence confirming what they fear.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: For 5000 years, no foreign army has desecrated the land of Japan. All of you must fight like Nipponjin. In the name of our fathers who held back the Russian marauders at Port Arthur and Mukden, and our forefathers before that who fought against the invasions of the mongols over 600 years ago, I ask each of you to defend this island to the limit of your strength. No man must die until he has killed at least ten Americans. We will hold Iwo Tou until the last of us has perished. Long live the Emperor! The MEN raise their hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: . Long live the Emperor! Banzai! Banzai! Banzai! TROOP’S CAVE - LATER . 49 Nozaki pulls out his money. A few bills and some coins. He pours them into an envelope. Other soldiers follow suit, collecting money and small trinkets of value, folding them into letters. ' Saigo similarly places his bills into an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: The armada of American ships makes its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ke 5 51 INT. BARON NISHI’S QUARTERS - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron Nishi composes a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : Keep warm and safe. I will fight courageously in the spirit of Yamato. Do not expect my return. In the end, I would just like to say, my heart has always been with you. Takeichi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 INT. TROOP’S CAVES - NIGHT A soldier passes out clean socks and towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men strip, changing into clean clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, the men face a religious altar adorned with zig-zag strips of paper (gohei). They bow before it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi is contemplative as he looks over letters sent from his family -- the scrawl of his youngest daughter, the elegant calligraphy of his wife’s hand and finally, the bold strokes from his son. He slowly folds them and takes out his pen.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Taro, I will fight as a son of Kuribayashi, the Samurai, and will behave in such a manner as to deserve the name of Kuribayashi. Now is the time for you to step up and lead the family. The life of your father is like a flicker of flame before the wind. 54 INT. TROOP’S CAVES ~ NIGHT : 54 Saigo picks up a cotton BELT with numerous stitchings. He puts it on and boasts to Nozaki.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: No one can shoot me now.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nozaki looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s a nice belt. My wife sent Me one too. Nozaki picks up a similar belt. He looks around the room. Some of the other soldiers have similar belts. He looks at Shimizu.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look like Mr. Kempeitai has a thousand-stitch belt, does he?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Maybe he thinks it will clash with his uniform. He probably doesn’t believe in superstitions, anyway. Shimizu finally picks up a similarly stitched belt.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKT
dialogues.text: His mother made him one after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The island is clouded in LARGE BLACK PLUMES as it is pounded relentlessly by planes flying sorties, dropping Mega-ton BOMBS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo’s unit is amassed at their position in the volcano dressed in uniform, some wearing their thousand-stitch belts. The entire GROUND SHAKES with each BOMB. Saigo and Nozaki can barely keep upright after each blast.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Maybe they're trying to sink the island.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: My head hurts.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: How many ships do you think there are out there?

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: At least 30. Maybe even 50.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKT
dialogues.text: They must be really close. Saigo gets up.

dialogues.speaker: .SAIGO
dialogues.text: I need to take a leak.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Don’t go near the sewers. I heard dysentery is spreading through there.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Where do I go then?

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: There’s a pot, at the end of the cave. Saigo takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troops eat their morning ration of porridge. Captain Tanida enters, adjusting his pants.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Someone needs to go throw out the shit pot. The men put their heads down, concentrating on their food, trying not. to be picked.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Saigo! Saigo reluctantly gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: And Saigo, if anything happens to that pot, you'll be carrying our shit away with your hands.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo picks up the CHAMBER POT, holding it at a distance with disgust. He makes his way through a —-

dialogues.speaker: CAVE NETWORK
dialogues.text: -- and finally comes to an -- OUTLET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo carefully navigates around the base of Suribachi. He comes to a crag and dumps the filthy contents of the bowl. Saigo looks up to see the ARMADA OF SHIPS -- an imposing mass of 485 ships converged around the island. The sight of the enormous fleet causes Saigo to drop the bowl. It tumbles down into a crevice.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: No! Saigo reaches down into the crevice, tries to retrieve the bowl, but can't reach it.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Damn! Suddenly, a WHISTLING NOISE causes Saigo to run for cover. A BOMB EXPLODES, sending sand flying in the air. PUFFS OF WHITE SMOKE off the ships convey that a SHOOTING BARRAGE has begun. Dark FIREBALLS and GEYSERS of black sand and rubble ERUPT over the landscape. Saigo crawls back towards the crevice and tries to reach down again without success. He looks up to the Heavens.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of joke? What kind of God are you? Making us suffer like this! You're probably laughing aren't you? You think this is funny.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Saigo looks around and finds-a STICK. He’fishes down in the crevice and catches the bowl on the end of the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully, carefully, he raises the stick, balancing the bowl on it. A BOMB EXPLODES in the sand yards away from him. But determined, Saigo manages to keep it steady. At last he pulls it up and takes it with relief, then runs for the caves. As he runs, a BOMB SHELL falls in his path. Saigo drops into the sand, still holding the pot, bracing for the explosion, but nothing happens. Saigo slowly gets up and stares at the dud. He looks to the Heavens.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Thank you, God. I take back what I said before. You are truly great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi peers through his binoculars. General Sato and Admiral Ichimaru stand at his side, also monitoring the activity. He sees GUNBOATS and DESTROYERS approaching the island.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ICHIMARU
dialogues.text: Shall we commence fire?

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: It’s not yet time. Hundreds. of LANDING CRAFTS hunker on to the beaches, Marines pouring out of their hulls.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ICHIMARU
dialogues.text: The men wish to commence firing.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Tell them to hold their fire.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ICHIMARU
dialogues.text: (into the radio) Hold your fire! Hold your fire! General Sato looks angrily at Kuribayashi.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL SATO
dialogues.text: The Americans will have the beach in no time if there is no resistance.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Let them land until there is no more room for reinforcements. He continues to watch with binoculars. Amphibious vehicles converge on the beach like a swarm of bees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the viewpoint of one of the beach pillboxes, the massive number of approaching Americans is even more frightening. A PILLBOX GUNNER looks on nervously, clasping his automatic weapon.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL ICHIMARU, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hold your fire! A BARRAGE of RIFLE FIRE and SEMI-AUTOMATIC BULLETS fly in from the amassing American army. The Gunner ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi peers through his binoculars again. The beach is flooded with MARINES and VEHICLES. ‘TANKS, trying to make their way, mire in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how they’ve bunched up there on the beach? There’s no room to advance or retreat. General Sato looks through his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Give the order. Commence firing.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL TCHTMARU
dialogues.text: (on the radio) Begin firing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a Men at the windows of their caves UNLEASH FURY, FIRING with MACHINE GUNS onto the beach. Saigo runs between the interconnected caves, supplying ammo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron Nishi stands by his men as they load a concealed tank unit.

dialogues.speaker: BARON NISHI
dialogues.text: Fire! The FORCE of the FIRE causes the tank to recoil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. SURIBACHI BEACH — DAY 64 The American marines are FIRED UPON from every direction. MINES BLOW, soldiers fall. Men and machines disintegrate. A marine runs up the beach and throws a grenade into a pillbox. The pillbox & bodies of the Japanese gunners fly. Another marine with a FLAMETHROWER INCINERATES a hidden pillbox and Japanese soldiers run screaming out in flames. INT. SURIBACHI CAVES - DAY oo 65 Shimizu and Nozaki FIRE DOWN on the marines. The flamethrower is GUNNED DOWN. EXT. MOTOYAMA MOUNTAIN -— DAY 66 The chaos of GUNFIRE, SHELLS and HOWLING ROCKETS ECHO through the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi fields reports from his officers.

dialogues.speaker: A LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: The gun emplacement of the Kitakubo Unit Was destroyed. Also, pillbox units on the beach have all been taken or destroyed. However, all other forces are intact and we estimate more than a thousand enemy casualties. Kuribayashi beams proudly.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: The pillbox destruction was unavoidable. Overall, that is good news. How are the men holding up at Suribachi?

dialogues.speaker: LI. FUJITA
dialogues.text: Forces are intact.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Good. Good. What is the enemy situation? f LT. FUJITA a Enemy strength is estimated at approximately 20,000 men and 80 tanks.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: No. There are far more than that. They still have soldiers waiting to land in their boats.

dialogues.speaker: LT. FUJITA
dialogues.text: At present, the enemy bridgehead extends between South Landing and Futatsune Iwo, with its depth greatest in the vicinity of the Western tip of Chidori airfield. Kuribayashi looks at the map.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHLI
dialogues.text: Just as I thought. They are making a two-pronged attack. Suribachi and the Motoyama ~ A airfield.

dialogues.text: Saigo, Shimizu, Nozaki and the other men line up in formation. They salute Col. Adachi as he makes his way among the men.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: Well done, men. You have proven yourselves today as worthy soldiers. As reward, you have earned Imperial Gifts. Each man is given one CIGARETTE and one piece of CANDY. The soldiers bow and gratefully take their booty.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: Infinite is the graciousness of our Emperor. Lighters are passed around, as each soldier savors his cigarette. INT. BARON NISHI’S CAVE - NIGHT 69 Baron Nishi’s troop, in contrast, are more relaxed, already seated on the ground with cigarettes. Baron Nishi lifts a-bottle of liquor to toast his men and takes a swig. He still wears his boots with spurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo and Shimizu sit by the cave entrance on night guard duty. Compared to the chaos of the daytime bombardment, the night air is relatively silent, interrupted only by occasional SPORADIC FIRE. Saigo starts to drift, his hand slipping off his rifle. Shimizu nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Hey! Saigo wakes up, quickly picking up his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: You were dozing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Saigo stands, stretches, and goes to the cave opening. He watches the bright NIGHT FLARES flying into the air.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Reminds me of the summer fireworks at Obon season. Saigo wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: You were from Kanagawa-ken, right? wo Shimizu nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Before I moved out to Tokyo, I _ grew up in Yokota. In Akita Prefecture. Saigo reflects, while Shimizu remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: It doesn't feel like February here. Right now, there would be lots of snow back home. It's right about the time that the village children would be building kamakura. They'd be building snow houses lit with lanterns, offering toasted mochi cakes and warm amazake to passersby. All along the river, tiny white houses lit with candles. It’s really something you ought to see. The pure white snow, the river, the warm glow of the candles... Saigo reflects on the image in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: (softly) I've heard about it. I would have like to have visited Akita once. There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: You’re not really Kempeitai are you? If you were, you wouldn't be here now. Shimizu doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: If there’s something you don’t want: anyone to know, I’m good at keeping secrets. Shimizu looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: Our shift is ended. It’s time to go back in. He gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORTARS pound the mountain. Ozawa mans a gunner position.

dialogues.speaker: OZAWA
dialogues.text: I need more ammo! Saigo picks up a machine gun tray, when suddenly the CAVE MOUTH EXPLODES with a direct hit. Ozawa is blasted to the back of the wall, his left arm torn off. He SCREAMS in pain, goes into shock, then slumps over dead. : Saigo rushes to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Ozawa! Captain Tanida emerges.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Saigo, take his place.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: The machine gun’s blasted.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Use your rifle. \ Saigo clumsily tries to undo the safety of his gun. As he does so, his gun points at Tanida.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Watch out! Imbecile!

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN TANIDA
dialogues.text: Saigo, forget about the rifle. Your shots have always been useless. Go send a report to Col. Adachi that we need another machine gun. Saigo is inwardly triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Saigo runs through the network of caves. He hears SCREAMS as men are hit by direct SHOTS. SMOKE and DUST fill the caves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi watches again with binoculars. The EXPLOSIONS are spectacular. Relentless.

dialogues.speaker: LT, FUJITA
dialogues.text: Sir, Suirbachi is taking a pounding. Col. Adachi is asking for reinforcements.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: We cannot send reinforcements. Tell him to hold out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimizu and Nozaki man a machine gun position. The HOWLING of BLASTS and SHELLS ECHOES throughout. Shimizu’s body reverberates as’ he controls the machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American Marines rush towards the mountain. One Marine heads straight for shimizu s hole, with a live grenade in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: Shoot him. Shimizu aims the gun at him, but it’s jammed, He hits the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED: “74

dialogues.speaker: NOZAKI
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SHIMIZU
dialogues.text: It’s jammed! The American keeps rushing. Shimizu fumbles for his pistol, but in his nervousness, his hand shakes. He drops the pistol. Just as the American is about to throw the live grenade, he is shot down. The GRENADE EXPLODES in his hand. Nozaki holds the smoldering pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saigo arrives at Adachi's cave. Col. Adachi looks tired and beat. He nervously sucks on a cigarette as he speaks into a radio transmitter. Saigo waits for him to finish.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: General, we are losing Suribachi. It’s all lost. Request permission to lead a suicide mission at 2100 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuribayashi hears Adachi’s haggard voice.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: No. No suicide missions. You and your men must try to hold out. If all fails, join forces in the North caves.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But, sir. I have failed to hold Suribachi. Permit me to die with honor with my men. KURIBAYASHI © No, Colonel, this is an order ~~ The LINE IS cur and it turns to STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: KURIBAYASHI
dialogues.text: Adachi... -Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 718 57. INT. ADACHI’S CAVES - DAY ; 17 There is just STATIC on the WIRE. Col. Adachi finally turns to Saigo, his eyes bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Sir, Captain Tanida requests to have a machine gun team sent to his area.

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: It's lost. It’s all lost.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Six?

dialogues.speaker: COL. ADACHI
dialogues.text: Suicide. It’s the only thing left. Your men should commit suicide. Adachi scribbles a NOTE.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: But the General--

dialogues.speaker: ADACHI
dialogues.text: Here, take this to your commander. Saigo takes the note. He looks back at Adachi who goes back to sucking his cigarette and staring at the cave wall. Saigo retreats through the caves with the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Captain Tanida stares at the note. It reads “Jiketsu” (mass suicide). The men are solemnly gathered around, knowing what.is to come.

dialogues.speaker: SAIGO
dialogues.text: Captain, I heard General Kuribayashi order Col. Adachi to escape -~

dialogues.text: Quiet! Escape is the coward’s way. Sit down!

dialogues.text: Ai ghllmaebenater soe seen nt tit
